title: Cat. 155  Evening, Little Waterloo Bridge, 1896
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 1551896Way: 119  
Levy: 165  
Transfer lithograph with stumping, drawn on white transfer paper with a grained-stone texture  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower right  
Two states; first state image size: 93 × 194 mm; second state image size: 121 × 194 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 26 (without distinguishing two states)  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 151, 309, 318  
Posthumous edition: 45 impressions printed by Goulding on 6 May 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 111, 153, 171, 174, 211, 216, 219, 220, 282, 324  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: app. II.4  
Selected Literature: Way (1912), p. 128  
Lifetime Exhibitions: New York 1898 (no. 361, as Evening, Little Waterloo); Chicago 1900b (no. 104).

Evening, Little Waterloo Bridge is one of eight lithographs (cat. 154, cat. 155, cat. 156, cat. 157, cat. 158, cat. 159, cat. 160, and cat. 161) drawn at the Savoy Hotel in London, where Whistler and his wife resided during February and March 1896. Their rooms at the top of the elegant hotel afforded them expansive views of the Victoria Embankment and the Thames. Working on transfer paper, Whistler drew two views of Waterloo Bridge, this image and another scene recorded at dawn (cat. 156). Although captured from slightly different vantage points within the hotel, both views look east from the Savoy to where Waterloo Bridge spans the Thames, linking the Embankment to the warehouses and wharves crowding the south side of the river.

Savoy Pigeons (cat. 154) and Evening, Little Waterloo Bridge are probably the earliest of Whistler’s Savoy lithographs. On 11 March 1896 Whistler sold proofs of these two images to Wunderlich’s in New York. In a letter written a few days later to Edward Kennedy, he described the two lithographs as “fresh out of the oven.” In all likelihood, they are the two subjects that were transferred and proved by the Ways on March 10 (app. II.4).

In Evening, Little Waterloo Bridge, the sense of fading daylight is evoked by the long shadows beneath the piers of the bridge and by their reflections in the water on the near side of the bridge. Once the drawing had been transferred, Whistler worked directly on the stone in the Ways’ nearby offices on Wellington Street, using crayon and a stump to enhance the effect of twilight’s darkening skies and gathering mists.

In the image as originally drawn and transferred, before additions to the stone, there are traces of stump work on the far right side of the bridge and in the sky, although the latter were too delicate to transfer effectively and print consistently.

Chicago: AIC, cream laid paper (202 × 314 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid paper (229 × 283 mm), signed. Washington: NGA, cream laid paper (230 × 284 mm), signed.

Revisions have been made directly on the stone with both crayon and stump. The majority of the additions were made in the sky to suggest cloud formations. The far shore has been extended and further delineated. Additions have been made to suggest smoke and mist across the river above the shoreline. The buildings at right on the distant bank have been strengthened in tone.

Chicago: SC, ivory laid paper (199 × 323 mm). Glasgow: HAG (6), cream laid paper (198 × 268 mm); cream laid paper (199 × 269 mm); cream laid paper (199 × 323 mm); ivory laid paper (202 × 322 mm); cream laid paper (200 × 323 mm); cream laid paper (199 × 270 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (197 × 269 mm), signed; LC, cream laid paper (199 × 307 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other second-state impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; Cleveland, CMA; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi
